Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a high resolution accurate mass spectrometer system
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program, Professor Bruce Macher from San Francisco State University and colleague Ten-Yang Yen will acquire a benchtop high resolution/accurate mass LC/MS/MS system. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels. Research areas to be addressed with the new instrument include protein structure, proteomics, biomarker discovery, protein-protein interactions, the development of enzyme inhibitors, the mapping of post-translational modification sites on proteins, the chemistry of singlet oxygen and oxidative methods in organic chemistry, and the chemistry of fulvenes and their application to organic synthesis.

An LC/MS/MS system combines the physical separation capability of liquid chromatography with the mass analysis ability of mass spectrometry. The liquid chromatograph separates a mixture into its molecular components. The separated components flow into the mass spectrometer where they are ionized into a parent ion and fragment ions and their mass/charge ratio are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows determination of the masses and chemical composition of the substances in a complex mixture. The instrumentation provided by this award will provide faculty and students in several departments the opportunity to pursue research projects using state-of-the-art instrumentation. It will also be used in several laboratory courses to train significant numbers of women and students from underrepresented minority groups in the use of this important and widely applied analytical tool.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding was provided through the NSF Major Research Instrumentation Program to purchase a mass spectrometer which has been used by faculty, postdoctoral scholars and students to obtain information for research projects, for training students in the latest technology in mass spectrometry and to enhance the educational offerings of San Francisco State University. Our major goals were to (i) install and maintain the new instrument within our Mass Spectrometry Facility, (ii) support SFSU faculty research programs by assisting them with experimental analyses, and (iii) to provide SFSU students, including those students supported by programs to increase the diversity of the science, engineering and mathematics workforce, with training on the use of the instrument. Twelve faculty members, three postdoctoral scholars and more than forty students utilized the new instrument during the 3 year funding period. The instrument will continue to serve the needs of faculty and students for several more years. Data obtained from utilizing the new instrument supported funded projects (NSF and NIH), and as preliminary results from research proposals. In addition, San Francisco State University faculty have been able to establish collaborative research projects with scientists from major universities in the U.S., Europe and Asia.

 

Training the next generation of scientists is a critical mission of SFSU faculty and NSF. Among the students involved in research projects who relied on the new instrument, ten M.S. degree students and nine undergraduate degree students completed their degrees within the 3 year funding period. These students have either moved to doctoral programs (4 students), M.S. degree programs (4 students) or accepted positions in the biotechnology or chemical industries. SFSU serves a highly diverse student body, many of who continue onto Ph.D. programs and become members of the scientific community at large. The new instrument provides valuable training to these students who are becoming part of the scientific enterprise.

 

San Francisco State University faculty, postdoctoral scholars and students have disseminated the results of work completed with the new instrument by publishing thirteen articles in scholarly journals and through 19 scientific conference presentations. These processes of scientific information dissemination ensure that other scientists are informed about critical scientific advances achieved with the new instrument and enhances the careers of San Francisco State University faculty and students. San Francisco State University’s infrastructure has been significantly enhanced by the availability of the new instrument obtained via NSF funding and the University is dedicated to ensure that the instrument will continue to function and support the major goals put forward within the original proposal.
